title: What is a college called in England? - Quora
tags: Colleges and Universities in the United Kingdom

response.answer_text: In English English, the word you are looking for is ‘college’, pronounced ˈkɒlɪdʒ/ (In American English it’s pronounced ˈkɑːlɪdʒ/ ) In Britain defined as a place where students go to study or to receive training after they have left school, a college of further education (providing education and training for pupils over 16), or a secretarial college or similar, or an institution, such as the Royal College of Art. (See community college.)ollege, sixth-form collegeAn organized group of professional people with special interests, duties or powers (such as the Royal College of Physicians).Also an Electoral College, defined as a group of people who are chosen to represent the members of a political party in the election of a leader.(From Oxford Advanced Learner's Dictionary: college noun - Definition, pictures, pronunciation and usage notes ) Hmmm… glad to be of service… (contented sigh). (See Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy)

College is used to describe a number of institutions: A school name for age 11–18 pupils, eg. Chessington Community College (CCC). It could have equally be named Chessington School. But it got the name CCC.A 6th form education. Institute for ages 16 and above. This typically will teach GCSE, GCE A Level, professional qualifications and degrees or part of degrees. For example Kingston College teaches parts of courses for degree programmes at Kingston University. This is in addition to other courses at different levels.It can be a part of a bigger university. E.g. Kings College Cambridge (part of Cambridge University), or Kings College London (part of London University). Some colleges are called schools e.g School of Oriental and African Studies (SOAS) at London University.It can be a professional body that represents professionals in a specific career. e.g. Royal College of Nursing. Other professional bodies are called Institute - e.g. Institute of Physics or the Institute of Engineering and Technology. They might also be called a Society, e.g. British Computer Society.
